trans-unit.source: A behavior is a re-usable aspect of an object that can be enabled or disabled without changing the component registry.
trans-unit.target: A behavior is a re-usable aspect of an object that can be enabled or disabled without changing the component registry.

trans-unit.source: A behavior is described by an interface, and has metadata such as a title and a description. The behavior can be looked up by a given short name or by the dotted name of the interface. With this unique name behaviors metadata can be looked up. When the behavior is enabled for an object, you will be able to adapt the object to the interface. In some cases, the interface can be used as a marker interface as well.
trans-unit.target: A behavior is described by an interface, and has metadata such as a title and a description. The behavior can be looked up by a given short name or by the dotted name of the interface. With this unique name behaviors metadata can be looked up. When the behavior is enabled for an object, you will be able to adapt the object to the interface. In some cases, the interface can be used as a marker interface as well.

trans-unit.source: A behavior is written much like an adapter, except that you don’t specify the type of context being adapted directly. For example:
trans-unit.target: A behavior is written much like an adapter, except that you don’t specify the type of context being adapted directly. For example:

trans-unit.source: A longer description for this behavior (optional).
trans-unit.target: A longer description for this behavior (optional).

trans-unit.source: A marker interface to be applied by the behavior. If
trans-unit.target: A marker interface to be applied by the behavior. If

trans-unit.source: A user friendly title for this behavior (required).
trans-unit.target: A user friendly title for this behavior (required).

trans-unit.source: Add name to behavior directive. This name can be used to lookup behavior registrations by new plone.behaviors.registration. lookup_behavior_registration function. [rnixx]
trans-unit.target: Add name to behavior directive. This name can be used to lookup behavior registrations by new plone.behaviors.registration. lookup_behavior_registration function. [rnixx]

trans-unit.source: Allow a marker-interface-only behavior to be set by using the ‘provides’ attribute (previously ‘interface’) in the <plone:behavior /> directive without a ‘factory’ attribute. The ‘marker’ attribute (previously known as ‘subtype’) is now only required if there is a marker used in addition to a behavior adapter with a separate interface (‘provides’) and factory. [optilude]
trans-unit.target: Allow a marker-interface-only behavior to be set by using the ‘provides’ attribute (previously ‘interface’) in the <plone:behavior /> directive without a ‘factory’ attribute. The ‘marker’ attribute (previously known as ‘subtype’) is now only required if there is a marker used in addition to a behavior adapter with a separate interface (‘provides’) and factory. [optilude]

trans-unit.source: An interface to which the behavior can be adapted. This is what the conditional adapter factory will be registered as providing (required).
trans-unit.target: An interface to which the behavior can be adapted. This is what the conditional adapter factory will be registered as providing (required).

trans-unit.source: As an example, let’s say that your application needs to support object-level locking. This can be modeled via an adapter, but you want to leave it until runtime to determine whether locking is enabled for a particular object. You could then register locking as a behavior.
trans-unit.target: As an example, let’s say that your application needs to support object-level locking. This can be modeled via an adapter, but you want to leave it until runtime to determine whether locking is enabled for a particular object. You could then register locking as a behavior.

trans-unit.source: Changed API methods and arguments to mixedCase to be more consistent with the rest of Zope. This is a non-backwards-compatible change. Our profuse apologies, but it’s now or never. :-/
trans-unit.target: Changed API methods and arguments to mixedCase to be more consistent with the rest of Zope. This is a non-backwards-compatible change. Our profuse apologies, but it’s now or never. :-/

trans-unit.source: If you find that you get import errors or unknown keyword arguments in your code, please change names from foo_bar too fooBar, e.g. enumerate_behaviors() becomes enumerateBehaviors(). [optilude]
trans-unit.target: If you find that you get import errors or unknown keyword arguments in your code, please change names from foo_bar too fooBar, e.g. enumerate_behaviors() becomes enumerateBehaviors(). [optilude]

trans-unit.source: In case a behavior is modified so that its dotted name changes, this field can be used to register the old name(s). Therefore, it is possible to retrieve the name(s) under which a behavior was formerly registered under.

trans-unit.source: New option to register a behavior only by it’s short name and not by it’s dotted name. This enables more advanced behavior subclassing capabilities. [jensens]
trans-unit.target: New option to register a behavior only by it’s short name and not by it’s dotted name. This enables more advanced behavior subclassing capabilities. [jensens]

trans-unit.source: Rename the ‘interface’ attribute of <plone:behavior /> to ‘provides’ to be more consistent with the <adapter /> directive. This is a backwards incompatible change! [optilude]
trans-unit.target: Rename the ‘interface’ attribute of <plone:behavior /> to ‘provides’ to be more consistent with the <adapter /> directive. This is a backwards incompatible change! [optilude]

trans-unit.source: Rename the ‘subtype’ attribute of <plone:behavior /> to ‘marker’ to be more explicit about its purpose. This is a backwards incompatible change! [optilude]
trans-unit.target: Rename the ‘subtype’ attribute of <plone:behavior /> to ‘marker’ to be more explicit about its purpose. This is a backwards incompatible change! [optilude]

trans-unit.source: plumbing, marker interface support needs to be enabled on a per-application basis. This package also does not directly support the adding of marker interfaces to instances. To do that, you can either use an event handler to mark an object when it is created, or a dynamic __providedBy__ descriptor that does the lookup on the fly (but you probably want some caching). A sample event handler is provided with this package, but is not registered by default
trans-unit.target: plumbing, marker interface support needs to be enabled on a per-application basis. This package also does not directly support the adding of marker interfaces to instances. To do that, you can either use an event handler to mark an object when it is created, or a dynamic __providedBy__ descriptor that does the lookup on the fly (but you probably want some caching). A sample event handler is provided with this package, but is not registered by default
